content: Fun clash, but I don't know how people are supposed to understand the "almost alphabetical" order rule in reverse mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear and simple but with a little bit of challenge on the special rule of C and H going first in the formula :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: combines chemistry with programming, teaching data processing, sorting, and formatting.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash that introduces some organic chemistry without being too difficult to solve or requiring lots of complex knowledge.

Any issues have been resolved and this should be a great clash.

Nice clash, I was able to solve in a few minutes.

Only things stopping me from approving:

1. The first test that tests for the correct alphabetical ordering of elements is 'Caffeine' and it appears quite late in the list. This is annoying for clashers in 'Fastest' mode because once you've seen 8 consecutive tests pass, it's very tempting to hit 'Submit', but then you end up failing test 9 (Caffeine in this case). It would be good to reorder things so that this edge case is tested a bit sooner.

2. The 'write' statement in your stub generator is multiline, which means that the IDE has two write statements (one for each line). This is confusing because it makes it seem like clashers need to output 2 lines when they don't. It's best to just keep the write statement to 1 line. You can use an OUTPUT command to add a comment to the output stub e.g.:
"write Chemical formula
OUTPUT
C, H, Alphabetical Order"

Former organic chemist here: looks fun.

Additional case possibility - a formula that contains 2 elements that begin with the same letter.
Example: N/Na, sodium nitroprusside (C5FeN6Na2O, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sodium_nitroprusside); O/Os- one example C23H19IN4OOs- find name in page for of the supplement https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/jm100560f

Possible extension of the clash (as a new one): do the empirical formulas- which is just the ratio of the elements.  If you don't wish to do it, would you mind if I did?

Goal
* Acetaminophen has 8 Carbon, not 3. Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol

* Please rewrite the last sentence as follows for clarity:
Given a list of atomic symbols that make up an organic compound, write its chemical formula.

Input
* Line 1: Please add the description of [[n]].

* Next n lines: Please add to the end of the description:
of an element that is part of the organic compound

Output
* Please add "of the organic compound" after "formula".

Cases
* Please swap the tests "Chloroform" and the validator "Methyl iodide", because both "Bromoform" and "Chloroform" feature an element where the number of atoms of a 2-letter element is greater than 1.

* Please delete the trailing newlines in the input of the last validator.

Thanks.

Things I noticed after a quick glance:

"Organic chemical formulas always contain the elements Carbon and Hydrogen." - The first two examples contains neither of them.

"The number following an element means the number of that element."  - Methane could be classed as C1H4 following that rule.

ok, i'll fix it
thanks
Can I change this to Ready now?

Possible extension of the clash (as a new one): do the empirical formulas- which is just the ratio of the elements.  If you don't wish to do it, would you mind if I did?

Sure!
1) What about Sodium ACetate?
I put a hint in the stub generator.

C2H3NaO2

The Na in the inputs comes before the O so my code passed this one before I added the correct sorting, just because my list of non-C and non-H elements was already ordered [Na, O].

I actually had C and H hardcoded to be ordered first already, then applied the others without sorting at first.

To make Sodium Acetate a good test for this, you should have O come before the Na in the inputs. :)

Let me know when you do, and I'll approve.
Ok; I'll make O before Na

Nice, I have approved now.

I didn't actually realise until after approving that this is enabled for Reverse mode. Seems a little bit hard for Reverse due to the specific ordering of the elements in the output... I'm not sure there are enough tests with multiple extra elements for Reverse clashers to be sure what the rule is... Maybe disable reverse? Or if not, then add some really complex ones with lots of elements so that the alphabetical sorting becomes more clear?

e.g. Chloramphenicol C₁₁H₁₂Cl₂N₂O₅, Halothane C₂HBrClF₃, ATP C₁₀H₁₆N₅O₁₃P₃, Methionine C₅H₁₁NO₂S, Thyroxine C₁₅H₁₁I₄NO₄
In the write statement, I gave them a hint: Chemical formula - C, H, Alphabetical order

That's useful, hopefully they see it. :)
I know I often delete the auto-generated code too quickly and miss hints, then end up having to CTRL+Z back to read them :P.
You've swapped the input of the relevant cases but haven't renamed them.
what about now?
I don't have further comments at the moment.
what about now?
